preReqs: One of PHYS 11, PHYS 12, PHYS 100. (plus Principles of Mathematics 12.)
description: General principles of the celestial sphere, laws of motion and light, optics, and telescopes; current knowledge of the Sun and Solar System.
title: Introduction to the Solar System

preReqs: One of PHYS 11, PHYS 12, PHYS 100. (plus Principles of Mathematics 12.)
description: Modern stellar and extragalactic astronomy. Stars and stellar evolution from protostars to black holes; galaxies and quasars; cosmology. ASTR 200/205 rather than ASTR 102 are recommended for students who intend to pursue studies in Astronomy.
title: Introduction to Stars and Galaxies

sections.comments: Note: Students having completed Physics 12 are also eligible for ASTR 102. If, however, you experience difficulty in registering, please contact the undergraduate programme coordinator at ugcoord@phas.ubc.ca.

preReqs: Either (a) one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157, PHYS 153 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121;  or (b) SCIE 001.
description: Stellar masses and evolution. White dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Extrasolar planet formation and detection. Dark matter in the Milky Way and other galaxies. Cosmological observations and principles.
title: Frontiers of Astrophysics

sections.comments: Please note, students MUST sign up for a tutorial section.
Students MUST sign up for a tutorial.

preReqs: ASTR 200 and one of PHYS 210, EOSC 211, CPSC 302, CPSC 303.
description: Measurement of positions, motions, and distances in astronomy.  Temperature, masses, and spectra of stars.  Hertzsprung-Russell diagram.  Quantitative stellar structure and evolution.  Chemical composition of stars in different Galactic populations. Globular and open star clusters.
title: Stars and Stellar Populations

preReqs: ASTR 205 and one of PHYS 210, EOSC 211, CPSC 302, CPSC 303.
description: Structure and kinematics of our galaxy. Spiral arms and dynamics of stars in spiral and elliptical galaxies. Galactic formation, evolution, dynamics, and groups. Active galaxies and quasars.
title: Galaxies

description: A survey of recent discoveries about the planets and other objects in the solar system, without the use of advanced mathematics. The Sun, the existence of planetary systems around other stars, and the search for life. Not open to first year students and not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science.
title: Exploring the Universe: The Solar System

sections.comments: This is a wait list section.
This is a wait list for a tutorial section. Please sign up on the wait list if your desired tutorial section is full or any of the current tutorial sections does not fit in your timetable.

preReqs: TERING FOR  THIS COURSE MUST SELECT A TUTORIAL TIME. TUTORIALS MEET EVERY OTHER WEEK.
description: A survey of recent discoveries in modern astronomy without the use of advanced mathematics. Stars, pulsars, black holes, galaxies, quasars and the origin and evolution of the Universe. Not open to first year students and not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science.
title: Exploring the Universe: Stars and Galaxies

sections.comments: STUDENTS REGISTERING FOR  THIS COURSE MUST SELECT A TUTORIAL TIME. TUTORIALS MEET EVERY OTHER WEEK.

As part of ASTR 311 Distance Education section 99C (Term 2), you are required to complete the online tutorial part of the course, however you do not need to register for the online tutorials in this DE section.
Tutorials for ASTR 311-T2A are every other week.
Tutorials for ASTR 311-T2B are every other week.
Tutorials for ASTR 311-T2D are every other week.
Tutorials for ASTR 311-T2G are every other week.
This is a wait list for a tutorial section. Please sign up on the wait list if your desired tutorial section is full or any of the current tutorial sections does not fit into your timetable.

preReqs: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 102, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 108, PHYS 117, PHYS 118, PHYS 131, PHYS 153, PHYS 157, PHYS 158, SCIE 001 and one of MATH 200, MATH 217, MATH 253, STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 241, BIOL 300, COMM 291, ECON 325, EPSE 482, EPSE 483, FRST 231, GEOG 374, KIN  371, POLI 380, PSYC 217, PSYC 218, PSYC 277, PSYC 278, PSYC 366, SOCI 328.
description: Observations and basic characteristics of extrasolar planets, including their formation, evolution, and potential for supporting life.
title: Exoplanets and Astrobiology

preReqs: EQUIRES DEPARTMENTAL APPROVAL. INTERESTED STUDENTS SHOULD CONTACT THE DEPARTMENTAL ADVISOR AND COURSE INSTRUCTOR IN ORDER TO REGISTER.
description: A research project, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a written report.  Requires approval of the course instructor and program advisor in the Department of Physics and Astronomy.
title: Directed Research Project in Astronomy

sections.comments: REGISTRATION REQUIRES DEPARTMENTAL APPROVAL. INTERESTED STUDENTS SHOULD CONTACT THE DEPARTMENTAL ADVISOR AND COURSE INSTRUCTOR IN ORDER TO REGISTER.

preReqs: One of PHYS 200, PHYS 250. (ASTR 300 is recommended.)
description: Introduction to the study of the Universe as a whole. Foundations of the Hot Big Bang model, the early Universe, nucleosynthesis, the cosmic microwave background, large-scale structure, galaxy formation and quasars. Credit will be granted for only one of ASTR 403 or PHYS 571.
title: Cosmology

sections.comments: *Note: PHYS 250 is also an eligible prerequisite. Students with PHYS 250 wanting to register in this course please contact the Physics  and  Astronomy Undergrad Program Coordinator with your student number for registration help.
This is a wait list section.

preReqs: All of PHYS 210, PHYS 408 and one of PHYS 312, MATH 316.
description: Astronomical instrumentation and techniques for ground and space-based observations. Theory of measurement, imaging, interferometry and spectroscopy of electromagnetic radiation at optical, radio, infrared, and X-ray wavelengths. Astronomical data analysis.
title: Astronomical and Astrophysical Measurements

description: Experiments in the use of astronomical instrumentation and data analysis. Use of the 40-cm reflector, spectrograph and electronic detectors. Photometric and spectroscopic analysis of digital data.
title: Astronomical Laboratory

preReqs: All of PHYS 203, PHYS 301, MATH 215 and ASTR 300.
description: Radiative processes. White dwarfs, neutron stars, and black holes. Accreting systems. Gamma-ray bursts.
title: High-Energy Astrophysics

preReqs: One of PHYS 210, EOSC 211 and one of MATH 217, MATH 227, MATH 317 and one of MATH 316, PHYS 312 and one of ASTR 200, EOSC 212.
description: Structure of planetary systems, planetary interiors, planet formation, planetary atmospheres, meteoritics, impact cratering.
title: Planetary Science

description: A research project in astronomy, undertaken under the direction of a faculty member, culminating in a thesis.
title: Honours Thesis in Astronomy
Directed Studies in Astronomy - DIRECTED STDS
